articles.headline: A Revolution in Prime Time, but Will It Work?
articles.snippet: A talk show costs a lot less than a scripted drama. If Jay Leno is only a modest success in the 10 p.m. slot, that could persuade other networks to change their strategies.
articles.abstract: A talk show costs a lot less than a scripted drama. If Jay Leno is only a modest success in the 10 p.m. slot, that could persuade other networks to change their strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  On Monday night, when Conan O’Brien officially takes over “The Tonight Show” from Jay Leno, it will mark an unusually peaceful transition of power in Hollywood.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: The 31-Year-Old in Charge of Dismantling G.M.
articles.snippet: Brian Deese, who had never even set foot inside an auto assembly plant, is the little-known hand behind the restructuring of the American automobile industry.
articles.abstract: Brian Deese, who had never even set foot inside an auto assembly plant, is the little-known hand behind the restructuring of the American automobile industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It is not every 31-year-old who, in a first government job, finds himself dismantling General Motors and rewriting the rules of American capitalism.

articles.headline: With Hollywood Sold, Imax Aims to Woo Wall St.
articles.snippet: A sharper focus on bringing huge-screen movies to the multiplex and not just the museum is beginning to pay off.
articles.abstract: A sharper focus on bringing huge-screen movies to the multiplex and not just the museum is beginning to pay off.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood has finally come to view Imax as a star. Will Wall Street be the next convert?

articles.headline: After Many Stumbles, the Fall of a Giant
articles.snippet: Rarely has a company fallen so far and so fast as General Motors, which ruled the car industry for over 50 years.
articles.abstract: Rarely has a company fallen so far and so fast as General Motors, which ruled the car industry for over 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a company that helped lift hundreds of thousands of American workers into the middle class. It transformed Detroit into the Silicon Valley of its day, a symbol of America’s talent for innovation. It built celebrated cars, like Cadillacs, that became synonymous with luxury.

articles.headline: In Crisis, Banks Dig In for Fight Against Rules
articles.snippet: Underlying a battle over derivatives trading is a broader debate over what the right amount of regulation is.
articles.abstract: Underlying a battle over derivatives trading is a broader debate over what the right amount of regulation is.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the financial crisis entered one of its darkest phases in October, a handful of the nation’s largest banks began holding daily telephone sessions. Murmurs were already emanating from Washington about the need for a wide-ranging regulatory overhaul, and Wall Street executives girded for a fight.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Don Van Natta Jr

articles.headline: Afghan Valley Offers Test for Obama Strategy
articles.snippet: The Jalrez Valley, where the U.S. has cut violence while improving services and creating jobs, is a test case.
articles.abstract: The Jalrez Valley, where the U.S. has cut violence while improving services and creating jobs, is a test case.
articles.lead_paragraph: JALREZ BAZAAR, Afghanistan  A year ago, the Taliban were tormenting this lush valley just miles from the Afghan capital, kidnapping people and blocking the road.

articles.headline: G.M. to Seek Bankruptcy and a New Start
articles.snippet: The bankruptcy is part of a plan that President Obama will outline on Monday morning to drastically shrink the automaker while keeping it competitive.
articles.abstract: The bankruptcy is part of a plan that President Obama will outline on Monday morning to drastically shrink the automaker while keeping it competitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David E. Sanger, Jeff Zeleny and Bill Vlasic, and written by Mr. Sanger.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Jeff Zeleny and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Preparing to Sell E-Books, Google Takes on Amazon
articles.snippet: Google plans to help publishers sell digital versions of new books direct to consumers, for use on phones or e-book readers.
articles.abstract: Google plans to help publishers sell digital versions of new books direct to consumers, for use on phones or e-book readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google appears to be throwing down the gauntlet in the e-book market.

articles.headline: Search Is On for Wreckage of Missing Air France Jet
articles.snippet: Vessels from Brazil, France and Spain were searching the Atlantic for the plane that disappeared while traveling from Rio de Janeiro to Paris with 228 people aboard.
articles.abstract: Vessels from Brazil, France and Spain were searching the Atlantic for the plane that disappeared while traveling from Rio de Janeiro to Paris with 228 people aboard.
articles.lead_paragraph: The disappearance of an Air France jet en route from Rio de Janeiro to Paris on Sunday evening left seasoned crash investigators with a mystery to plumb and very little data to work with.
articles.byline: By Donald G. McNeil Jr. and Christine Negroni

articles.headline: Obama Is Upbeat for G.M.’s Future
articles.snippet: President Obama described the investment of more billions of taxpayer dollars in G.M. as necessary to avert a calamity that could hurt millions of people.
articles.abstract: President Obama described the investment of more billions of taxpayer dollars in G.M. as necessary to avert a calamity that could hurt millions of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama marked the lowest point in General Motors’ 100-year history  its bankruptcy filing on Monday  by barely mentioning it, instead focusing his remarks on the second chance G.M. will have to become a viable company with more government aid.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Seeking Clues on Suspect in Shooting of Doctor
articles.snippet: The 51-year-old man had professed an anti-government, anti-abortion philosophy, some who knew him said.
articles.abstract: The 51-year-old man had professed an anti-government, anti-abortion philosophy, some who knew him said.
articles.lead_paragraph: OVERLAND PARK, Kan.  From the one-story house she once shared in this Kansas City suburb with her former husband, now suspected in the death of a doctor who performed late-term abortions, Lindsey Roeder recalled on Monday how he seemed to undergo a drastic personality shift more than a decade ago.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Monica Davey
